stream_context.summary: Bug-hunt and redesign session focused on Course 15. Kaze tries to stop a snowflake particle crash, debates texture approaches, and designs a new "zipper to hell" sub-area while fighting emulator problems.

development_findings.summary: Return to Yoshi’s Island is described as “getting close to completion,” but Kaze refuses to give any release date.
development_findings.quote: Please stop asking me for release dates. I will literally lose my mind.

development_findings.summary: Current blocker: a snowflake particle effect crashes Project64 but works on real N64; suspected memory corruption tied to styrofoam normal-mapped terrain.
development_findings.quote: At this point we have very conclusive evidence that it’s the styrofoam causing this.

development_findings.summary: Working on Course 15: adds tilting bridges, springs, and a secret ‘zipper to hell’ area with cardboard platforms.
Design pivot: replace styrofoam snow with cardboard sheets stapled to the ground and use normal-mapped grass only; expected to cut overdraw and improve FPS.
development_findings.quote: Replace styrofoam with cardboard and paper staple… I think that was a good idea by Biobak.

development_findings.summary: Optimization pass: vertex-buffer math, removing hidden polygons, and splitting mountain materials; RDP now main bottleneck, game thread ~12 ms.
Engine now sustains 30 FPS on real N64 even with big models like Isle Delfino; antialiasing costs ~15 % performance.
development_findings.quote: Easy 30 fps on N64… antialiasing off 23 fps, on 26.

development_findings.summary: Field-of-view toggle for widescreen; sacrifices side pixels for 10 FPS gain.
Multiplayer renderer rewritten; old 60 FPS flicker method dropped in favor of shared draw to avoid doubling the mat stack.
ROM size target fixed at 64 MB; Kaze jokes about marketing it as the first 'quadruple-A' N64 game.
development_findings.quote: I’m going to say this is the first quadruple A N64 game ever.

development_findings.summary: Shell-texturing kept only for small actors because it is ‘extremely expensive’.

context_findings.summary: Continuous frustration with power outages, stream viewer drops, and emulator instability.
Kaze’s core motivation is making games, not videos; hires an editor and experiments with Twitter ad revenue.
context_findings.quote: If it was up to me, I just wouldn’t make videos at all, but then I can’t do my thing as a hobby that makes money.

context_findings.summary: Day-job is programming; Return to Yoshi’s Island is a hobby project done after hours.
context_findings.quote: No, my main job is not this; my main job is programming for a company.

context_findings.summary: Acknowledges legal risk: a commercial PC release would need all Mario assets removed to avoid Nintendo action.
context_findings.quote: Obviously I would have to remove all the Mario assets… Nintendo would sue.

biobak.summary: Suggested replacing problematic styrofoam terrain with cardboard/paper, including graded rim coloring for depth; Kaze accepts and adds to to-do list.
Role clarified: optimizes and beautifies maps; sometimes makes them heavier but finds offsets.
biobak.quote: Biobak isn’t there to optimize the maps; he’s there to make them prettier and he sometimes finds some optimizations along the way.

key_stories.title: The Snowflake Crash Hunt
key_stories.summary: A seemingly simple particle effect causes crashes only on Project64. Kaze chases vertex math, inline functions, and memory allocations before suspecting the styrofoam terrain as the real culprit.
key_stories.challenge: Game crashes when snowflakes spawn in Course 15 on one emulator.
key_stories.process: Single-step assembly, compare emulator vs. real N64, isolate vertex-buffer math, disable effects.
key_stories.outcome: Not fully solved on-stream; strong evidence points to styrofoam causing memory corruption; fix postponed.
key_stories.key_quote: How does changing the function from an inline to not an inline make it work? This garbage emulator, man, I swear.

key_stories.title: Styrofoam Gets the Boot
key_stories.summary: Visual snow terrain used normal-mapped styrofoam but looked bad and triggered crashes. After Biobak’s suggestion, Kaze decides to replace it with cardboard sheets stapled to the ground and keep normal-mapped grass.
key_stories.challenge: Styrofoam normal map both ugly and crash-prone.
key_stories.process: Discuss alternatives with chat; test grass-only normal map; evaluate performance.
key_stories.outcome: Task added: 'replace styrofoam with cardboard and paper staple'; expected FPS gain and aesthetic improvement.
key_stories.key_quote: Do we even want the normal map styrofoam? I don't think it does look good.

key_stories.title: Emulator Compatibility Nightmare
key_stories.summary: Return to Yoshi’s Island runs flawlessly on real hardware but various emulators crash or demand weird settings. Kaze vents about Project64 and Parallel, considering forcing players to one known-good build.
key_stories.challenge: Inconsistent emulator behavior jeopardizes user experience.
key_stories.process: Test different cores, inline vs. non-inline functions, assess CPU usage, consider public stance.
key_stories.outcome: No technical fix yet; possible policy: 'use Project64 1.6 or real N64.'
key_stories.key_quote: What if we just force people to stop using Parallel?

open_questions.topic: Final root cause of the snowflake crash
